I'm so scared only because it makes me feel like my original lump was misdiagnosed and I might have missed my chance to treat any cancer. I'm under 30 with a family history and I just know exactly how you feel. 21 is on the very young side so that does put you in a much lower risk category. I know it happens at all ages but hopefully that comforts you. I will pray for you and hopefully you all will do the same for me. You really never know with these things and I'm fearing the worst since my breast lump is huge and lymph node issues are never a good sign with a pre-existing breast lump. I can't think of anything else it could be. I never get sick ever so I'm very nervous.

Posts.Title: ? about BSE beepbeep VSM

Posts.Content: Nov 7, 2011 07:41PM - edited Nov 7, 2011 07:41PM by beepbeep i'm sorry you are going thru this stress at 23. i'm pretty high risk for bc and have been dodging testing for some time now. from what i understand (please correct me if i'm wrong), you are still at pretty low risk right now and vigilant surveillance is an option for you. i'd have your lump looked at for sure but try to remember that benign is much more common for your age group (even with the gene). whatever you decide will be the right thing for you. my friend just had a prophylactic mastectomy and she's doing great! she's in her 30's and said her recovery has been good.surgery is so much less invasive now that i really dont think it distorts you in any noticeable way. but i think many women choose more conservative methods and are happy with that too. just do yourself a favor and make sure you are at least getting a breast exam twice a year!!! preferrably some kind of screening once or twice a year.. even if it's just an ultrasound. best of luck!!!!
Posts.Title: 23, mom, brca+ now what jenamae denouement

Posts.Content: Dec 30, 2011 06:20PM beepbeep wrote: It really depends on your situation. With a family history like mine, I should have been checking myself once a month and getting a clinical exam at least once every few years. I'm under 30 now but hadn't done any thorough checking until this year... and hadn't been to the doctor either for years!!!  Unless you have a strong family history, I'd say get a clinical exam at least once every few years and check yourself out at least a few times a year. If you can handle it, check your breasts once a month. I can't stand giving myself breast exams. I'm pretty lumpy and I can't tell what's normal. It's exhausting, but I've had a biopsy recently so I check my problem breast constantly!! Do what you can but.... at least do more than I did!!! Best of luck!
Posts.Title: When did you first checking for lumps? lookingaround beepbeep

Posts.Content: Nov 9, 2011 08:33PM beepbeep wrote: agree with cycle... i have a high tolerance of pain so i was able to get over it quickly but one of my biopsy *clicks* hurt me horribly but i had the ability to ask for more anesthestic. i just chose not to because it was the last *click* and the pain went away immediately. it's not supposed to be painful and you always have the option to ask for more lidocaine. mine actually hurt but it still wasn't bad. i'd do it again if i needed to. even with pain, it's easy to tolerate if you have a supportive doc.

Posts.Content: Nov 21, 2011 08:11PM beepbeep wrote: As emotionally draining as it can be, I think all palpable lumps should be biopsied. I worry sometimes when doctors speak about initiatives to reduce biopsies in young women. I feel like I'm hearing more about young people getting BC than older people. I can't believe how many women on this site along got cancer between 28 and 35. Am I missing something? What's the harm in self exam and clinical exam? I went many years without checking and it wasn't smart of me. I might have been able to track my current lump better if I had known more about it. There's no such thing as being "too careful" with breast cancer. The only thing I take issue with is giving a mammogram to a young woman without good reason. My sister has had 6 mammograms and the only indication for it was a benign cyst that was diagnosed through ultrasound. 6 mammograms in someone under 35!!! I don't care for that but then again, it's all we really have for screening.
Posts.Title: Breast cancer screening guide says skip exams Chickenpants Chickenpants

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2012 03:59PM beepbeep wrote: Sorry to hear about your breast stress, skapaya. I hear you loud and clear! Once I found my first lump, I've been on a 24/7 lump hunt. I  went from almost never touching my breasts to going over them with a fine toothed comb. All the while having no real idea what I'm feeling. It becomes an acute awareness even if the lump is benign.  I'm on your side and praying that this will be completely benign. Sounds likely to be something harmless but you are still in my thoughts.

Posts.Content: Nov 30, 2011 12:44PM - edited Nov 30, 2011 12:46PM by beepbeep Prayers are with everyone going through cancer or the possibility. Eileen - nice to hear that your doctor is being positive. I'm sorry to hear that you skipped mammograms but please don't beat yourself up. Health screenings are scary and I get that completely. I hope you will be vigilant with them regardless of your results and I sincerely hope they  come back NEGATIVE!!  My mom only skipped two mammos and I think she would still be alive today had she gotten at least one in between. The hard truth is- nobody expects to get cancer, especially at younger than average ages, so I understand why people skip things.    I'm so sorry Kite about your news. I hope your treatment is very successful and that you find comfort here!

Posts.Content: Dec 30, 2011 05:24PM beepbeep wrote: A few chunks of tissue were sampled and identified as "probably fibroadenoma" from biopsy but I have been noticing what seems like growth. One of my friends has told me she doesn't think it's grown. And I went to the doctor recently and she siad it felt less prominent... but it's not. I hate it because we're supposed to trust when a doctor says something like that but I simply know it's not true. This isn't smaller by any means and in fact seems bigger. I just dont know how much bigger. I dont think my doctor documented the size in her chart so I dont know where she got that from. I wonder at this point if I should switch doctors. It makes me nervous that she thinks it's smallr when it's not especially since fibroadenomas arent known to shrink until after menopause. I'm surprised a breast specialist wouldnt know that. It's just very scary to me.
Posts.Title: Can fibroadenomas grow within a few months? beepbeep rsilva559

Posts.Content: Nov 22, 2011 03:26PM beepbeep wrote: I don't see the point in abandoning CBE's as it's just a small part of the physical assessment. It takes less than 5 minutes and is probably one of the more important things to check for at an annual doctor appointment. I think the breast exam is more important than the pelvic exam to be perfectly honest. Breast cancer is more common and there's really no such thing as "average risk" since the overwhelming majority of cancer patients have no family history. Even young women that get breast cancer tend to have no family history. I agree that there should be a better screening method for youngsters. Ultrasounds serve a good purpose but they can be utterly useless at times. It was for my lump. MRI's are extremely invasive IMO. Maybe not medically but emotionally. I'd say laying down in a cylinder for 30 minutes could be very traumatic especially for a high risk woman who is already worried enough. I'm not even so sure about core biopsies anymore. Seems like anything with even a small risk of error is the wrong method to use. Bottom line, I hate breast cancer. I hate everything about this unforgiving disease. I hate that some women have to be more worried than other. I hate that women who thought they had no reason to worry get blindsided by this disease, often at young ages. My friend brought up a freaky story the other day. She said that there are people ready to test out cures but the health committee (or whatever it is) aren't giving them the green light. Then my friend said that the medical community might not want to find a cure because then they'd lose out on the money they gained from all these sick people. That's a scary thought. I hope that would never be true but is still freaky. They make a lot of money on sick people and eradicating a common disease would lose money from their perspective. Makes me feel a little queasy.
Posts.Title: Breast cancer screening guide says skip exams Chickenpants Chickenpants

Posts.Content: Nov 22, 2011 03:41PM beepbeep wrote: @Michelleo, I hope you are right. The sheer joy in finding a cure for a deadly disease should trump any financial losses! I want so badly to see a cure in my lifetime. It sends happy chills up my spine to think about the idea of a shot or pill being all that's needed to keep breast cancer from happening.
Posts.Title: Breast cancer screening guide says skip exams Chickenpants Chickenpants

Posts.Content: Nov 9, 2011 10:21AM - edited Nov 9, 2011 10:27AM by beepbeep even when it comes to family history, reports contradict themselves. many medical experts will say that most women with breast cancer (70-80%) have no family history... but then say that family history can double or triple your risk. which is it? i dont know if you mistyped but i think the studies say that it raises the risk 15% not 51%. dont want you thinking the # is that high!! take care everyone. like the breast cancer org site says... people who  are already high risk are more apt to do everything to avoid raising that risk further. i'm avoiding alcohol and birth control pills to be on the safer side but i know i could still get it just because of my family... and i also know that alcohol and ocp's are not the biggest risks. one thing i won't do is force myself to have a kid before 30 just because it *might* lower my risk.

Posts.Content: Dec 29, 2011 10:36AM beepbeep wrote: I think it's SO sweet for you to be  concerned about your lady. I'm very impressed by you for trying to help her in this way. I try not to say breast cancer is impossible for young women because it's unfortunately not... but 23 is on the very young side for such a disease. Nearly all the cases under 25 make headline news because it's extremely uncommon. Especially given that her family history does not sound terribly concerning. She needs to get a biopsy though if she;s worried. It will ease her mind more than any other test could. Personally, I'd opt for complete removal. I made the mistake of not having mine removed and I'm still worried sick about it to this very day. Your girlfriend will have a much easier recovery with such a small lump. Best of luck, I will be hoping good things!!! I feel very confident that your girlfriend does not have cancer but I think it's always best to get things completely checked out.
Posts.Title: Rapid growing lump in right breast pkel1988 beepbeep

Posts.Content: Nov 9, 2011 10:20AM beepbeep wrote: i wouldn't give too much credibility to these "risk factors". they say having your first child after 30 raises your risk but my mother had her first at 26 and still got cancer. most women with breast cancer i've known had children before 30. there's no rhyme or reason to cancer... especially at the young age you got it (so glad you are ok!). i'm not a drinker and i'm trying to avoid things that "may" contribute to higher estrogen levels to be on the safe side (i.e., hormonal birth control). but i don't believe for one second that someone  younger than 35 could cause cancer by drinking. that doesn't make sense. too many drinkers don't get cancer so that point could never really be valid.
